body: Update, I'm reasonably certain this is not the root cause of ChronicleEnterprise/Chronicle-Services#229 but I still think it could be an issue.

Will this proposal still work if you are using a concurrent event loop?

> On 2 Jun 2021, at 06:10, Nick Tindall ***@***.***> wrote:
> 
> ﻿
> Update, I'm reasonably certain this is not the root cause of ChronicleEnterprise/Chronicle-Services#229 but I still think it could be an issue.
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or unsubscribe.

I'm not sure to be honest, I listened to the dev meeting recording and Jerry mentioned that in a concurrent event loop individual handlers are still bound to a single thread, so we'd need a way to ensure the listener was called by the same thread associated with the TCPHandler.

I'm not sure about the details, but you are passed a `net.openhft.chronicle.network.NetworkContext` in `net.openhft.chronicle.network.cluster.ConnectionManager.ConnectionListener.onConnectionChange` and NetworkContexts don't look to be thread-safe so it seems dangerous that these Listeners can end up executing on the thread that adds them.
@nicktindall Is there any more to do for this issue?

> @nicktindall Is there any more to do for this issue?

I made a fix in Queue Enterprise which fixes the problem specifically when the ServerThreadingStrategy is not CONCURRENT. Which is an improvement, because I tried and its reasonably difficult to use CONCURRENT (you need to override the default EventGroup).

The problem in general is still there, and I'm not sure how to fix it generally. The issue is the TcpEventHandler manages the NetworkContext so if you call ConnectionManager.addListener and it ends up being executed synchronously on the calling thread there's a chance you'll be provided with a NetworkContext that is in the process of being closed.

There is an example of how to do this in a thread-safe manner [here](https://github.com/OpenHFT/Chronicle-Threads/blob/0ea446c474bbf23551f211eec09052fe002190d3/src/main/java/net/openhft/chronicle/threads/MediumEventLoop.java#L220) but its a bit more complicated in the case of the ConnectionManager because there's a chance that the ServerThreadingStrategy is CONCURRENT and each of the NetworkContexts is "owned" by a different thread.

The idea behind [this issue](https://github.com/OpenHFT/Chronicle-Core/issues/226) was that we might be able to add assertions to pick up these things in testing. For me (and, I assume, whoever wrote that code) it was a surprise that the event handler could be executed synchronously to introduce this issue.

issue.title: Execute new connection listeners on TCPEventHandler thread, Fixes #109

repository.name: Chronicle-Network

issue.body:
Fixes #109 

## Main points
- State required for idempotency moved out of ConnectionManager (would have been a small(?) memory leak previously)
- Will work with any ServerThreadingStrategy (including concurrent)
- Checks for new listeners should be fast in the event there are none (just an integer comparison, synchronized block only entered if there are new listeners to execute)
- onConnectionChanged should now only enter synchronized block if the state has actually changed

## Note to reviewers
One thing that I thought might be a risk was this implementation associates the state required for idempotency with the UberHandler (the `eventEmitterToken` field), where previously the last known state was stored in a map keyed by `NetworkContext`. If a single `NetworkContext` was able to be associated with multiple `UberHandlers` (simultaneously or sequentially) then that would be a change in behaviour, and potentially not idempotent. But from what I can see this is not the case and `UberHandlers` are 1:1 with `NetworkContexts`.
